title: PM Update: Scattered storms ending late this evening; warm and sunny Tuesday
text:
7:45 p.m. update: Much of the activity from earlier has died off and moved away. A few storms are passing the Manassas area and to the south/west of there. Other than that, and some storms in northern Md., there’s not much going on. Places well south and southwest of the city still run the risk of a passing storm, and a quick shower is possible elsewhere. Most folks should stay dry into the night. See below for the forecast through tomorrow!

From 3:15 p.m... Earlier storm updates at bottom...

The last day of summer (unofficially) felt rather summerlike. High humidity and temperatures well into the 80s have fueled a storm risk that will be with us through the evening. A few of these storms could be intense, mainly when it comes to heavy rain, but an isolated damaging wind gust isn’t impossible.

Listen to our daily D.C. forecasts: Apple Podcasts | Amazon Echo | More options

Through tonight: Scattered strong storms are a risk from late afternoon through the evening. The main shower and storm threat should tend to wane with sunset, but we’re not totally out of the woods till perhaps about 10 p.m. to midnight or so, especially south and east. After that, it’s partly cloudy, with maybe some patchy fog in places it rains. Lows range from the mid-60s to the low 70s.

View the current weather at The Washington Post.

Tomorrow (Tuesday): Some thicker cloudiness may linger into the morning — otherwise we’re partly sunny or sunnier for most of the day. Humidity is down a bit from today, but still moderate. Afternoon temperatures head for the mid-80s in most spots. Winds are variable and mainly out of the east and northeast.



The House of the Temple on 16th Street NW as storm clouds blow by overhead. (Rex Block/Flickr)

See Dan Stillman’s forecast through the weekend. And if you haven’t already, join us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter and Instagram. For related traffic news, check out Gridlock.

...Earlier storm updates...

6:30 p.m. update: Severe warned storms are passing south of the Beltway. The main severe weather threat is the potential for damaging winds, in addition to the general storm threats of heavy rain and frequent lightning. While this is the most intense activity in the area, additional showers and storms are still possible after it passes. Some are moving through the Middleburg area in western suburbs and a couple more may move in from the northwest this evening. Storms should tend to wane with sunset, but a few could last into the night before ending.

Severe Thunderstorm Warning including Lake Ridge VA, Burke VA, Marumsco VA until 7:00 PM EDT pic.twitter.com/ATFSRxaJ6O — NWS DC/Baltimore (@NWS_BaltWash) September 2, 2019

5:00 p.m. update: Scattered storms are marching across the area as we head into evening. A severe storm warning is up for parts of Loudoun, Fairfax, Fauquier, and Prince William counties until 5:30 p.m. This storm has produced some wind damage already and may continue to do so. The warned storm is moving southeast, with places like Manassas and Fairfax in line after 5:30. Additional showers and storms should try to pass through the immediate area over the next hour or so as well.
description: A few storms were intense. Sunshine is the story tomorrow.
